div.p:
THE IUSTICE OF THE ARMY Again≈øt Evill-Doers VINDICATED: BEING A brief Narration of the Court-Martials proceedings again≈øt
ARNOLD,
TOMSON, and
LOCKYER,
with the Cau≈øes and Grounds thereof.

By which the impartiall Reader may plainly judge, how hardly and unchri≈øtianly the≈øe men deale with the Army, to call that Arbitrary, Tyrannicall, Barbarous Murther, in them; which they could not omit without eminent neglect of their duty, and apparant danger of the mo≈øt de≈øperate events to the Parliament, Kingdome, and Army, that can be imagined.

q.p:
He that is fir≈øt in his own cau≈øe, ≈øeemeth ju≈øt, but his Neighbour cometh and ≈øearcheth him.

They are all grievous revolters, walking with ≈ølanders.

div.p: London, Printed by T. Paine, 1649.

I Should not have troubled my ≈øelf with Writing, nor You with Reading this following Di≈øcour≈øe, had it not been for their ≈øakes, who ignorantly without any malitious intent, ≈øpeake evill of things they know not: This being a time, wherein this way of Controverting things by printing, is become one of the greate≈øt vanities; but con≈øidering how all manner of Evill in the World, hath clothed it ≈øelf with Impudence, and more e≈øpecially that Spirit which rageth at this time in this Kingdom, again≈øt all per≈øons, and things that doe not bowe before it; I could not any longer, finding all other ≈øilent in this bu≈øine≈øse, forbeare the vindication of Truth and Iu≈øtice, again≈øt the clamors of men, at the ju≈øt and favourable proceedings of the Court-martiall, in the following ca≈øes.

And this I could not have forborn ≈øo long, had it not been out of tenderne≈ø≈øe to tho≈øe things which the≈øe rayling revilers have pretended to, who have dealt with the Army and their friends, as the mo≈øt barbarous of their Enemies in ≈øome Gari≈øons, have done in time of War in detaining ≈øome per≈øons, whom they Judged were highly e≈øteemed of by them, in their Cu≈øtody, to ≈øet in places of mo≈øt danger, to hinder them from a≈ø≈øaulting, this is the cheife≈øt u≈øe, the≈øe men have made of the
words Iu≈øtice, Righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, Liberty, and Freedome, &c to place them, in the Fronti≈øpice of their lies and ≈ølanders, that none might kill the latter, without wounding the former, and if J have in anything Interfer'd in this Di≈øcour≈øe, again≈øt tho≈øe good things; charge it upon my weakne≈ø≈øe, not upon my will, and the rea≈øon why I only give you the Relation of the≈øe three, and not of tho≈øe other ≈øince Executed for this la≈øt mutiny, is:
Fir≈øt, becau≈øe the mi≈ørepre≈øenting of the Armies proceedings again≈øt the≈øe fir≈øt, have been made u≈øe of to fit the Soldiers for, and to ≈øtirre them up unto this la≈øt.
Secondly, becau≈øe I expect it will be done by ≈øome other hand, more able then my ≈øelfe, to ob≈øerve and relate it.

Thirdly, becau≈øe I have not mett with any ≈øuch clamors and mi≈ørepre≈øentations of the latter, as again≈øt the former, which if I ≈øhould, I might well forbeare an≈øwering, there having been ≈øome per≈øons of Eminent integrity and ability, in≈ønared in the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, whom God hath made fully ≈øen≈øible of their evill therein, and will therefore bee mo≈øt fitt and able, to give a repre≈øentation thereof; I referre thee to what followes, and ≈øhall re≈øt thine, in the cau≈øe of Truth and Ju≈øtice,

div.head: The Ju≈øtice of the Army again≈øt evill doers vindicated.
div.p: HOw tender the ruling part of the Army hath been in taking away life by Martiall-law: Is ≈øo notorious, it needeth not my te≈øtimony; there being not executed to my be≈øt remembrance, above five or ≈øix, ≈øince the Generall had his Commis≈øion, be≈øides the≈øe Mutineers.

And for the fir≈øt of the≈øe, viz. Arnoll, who was ≈øhot to death at the Randevouze neer Hartford, I ≈øhall referr you to the Narration of Captain Bray, delivered in writing to the Generall, and Councell, and ≈øub≈øcribed by him, he being then an Officer of the ≈øame Regiment, and an Eye-witnes of all their mi≈øcarriages and out-rages; the ≈øub≈øtance whereof is, as followeth.

The Regiment being ordered to march to New-ca≈øtle, when they came at St. Albans, had the paper called the ca≈øe of the Army ≈øtated read unto them; upon which they re≈øolved unanimou≈øly not to march, ≈øaying, it was contrary to their Ingagement, to be devided, &c.

The next morning, according to the Orders I had received, I cau≈øed the Drums to beat, &c. but few or none would come to their Collours, but they flocked about me, and told me, they were re≈øolved not to march, whereupon I u≈øed all the Arguments of per≈øwa≈øion that I could, as many witne≈ø≈øes can te≈øtifie, &c: But it would not availe, they generally and unanimou≈øly ≈øeized upon the Collours, and ≈øet them in the Waggons, and ≈øet a ≈øtrong guard upon them, &c.

At a Councell of Warr held at Hockley, I gave my Vote for their marching, it pre≈øenting it ≈øelf, rea≈øonable to me al≈øo, &c. I returned from the Councell of Warr, and told them I had received Orders to march, and the rea≈øons thereof, and gave as many Arguments as I could to per≈øwade them, but they combined and con≈øulted together what to do, murmuring among them≈øelves, &c
and that night they came furiou≈øly into my Quarter, and demanded the Colours of me, but I denyed them my Colours, telling them that it was mo≈øt rea≈øonable, the Colours ≈øhould remain in my Cu≈øtody, &c: But they told me, they could not believe any of their Officers; nay, that they could not believe their own fathers, &c. So they went into the Chamber, and fetched the Colours, and ≈øet a ≈øtrong guard over them at the Waggons, &c.

And when I came to Olney, &c. they all determined not to march further; yet the next morning I commanded the Drums to beat, intending to march according to my Orders, &c. but the Companies came together, and unanimou≈øly re≈øolved not to march, though I propounded unto them all the Arguments of obedience and rea≈øon that I could; profe≈øsing, that though I was a friend, and ever would be, God willing, to all ju≈øt de≈øires, re≈øolutions, and mutuall ingagements, yet I was an enemy to irregularity. Whereupon they were ≈øu≈øpitious of me, that I was an enemy to ju≈øtice, and the liberty and freedome of the people.

Not long after, the ≈øame day, came more Colours from Northampton≈øhire, which made them more and more exorable; and by my pre≈øsing, I received an affront by a Cavalier, &c. who ≈øwore by the Name of God, they mu≈øt not believe any of their Officers, and that they mu≈øt fight again≈øt Independents, &c. Whereupon I fearing a de≈øigne de≈øtructive to the Army, Generall and Kingdome, I told them the ca≈øe of the Army ≈øtated, came from ≈øuch hands who were re≈øolved enemies to ≈øuch per≈øons, &c. ≈øo that I was bound in judgement and con≈øcience to the Nation, and to the Generals ju≈øt authority, to continue with them in this di≈øtemper, to keep off that unju≈øt de≈øigne which I feare per≈øons did endeavour to carry on, whom God hath in ≈øome mea≈øure di≈øcovered, and will more in due time, &c.

Whereupon they marched back, according to their own determinations, to Dun≈øtable, many of the Hor≈øe al≈øo having been among them full of di≈øtempers, &c. and there they received a Letter, the ≈øub≈øtance whereof was, that they ≈øhould ≈øtand (as I remember) to their hone≈øt ingagements for Souldiers rights, and Englands freedoms; and the party that brought the Letter to them, told them, the Generall, and Lieutenant Generall would
not oppo≈øe them, though they were not ≈øatisfied in the way yet: and the≈øe expre≈øsions made the Souldiers more and more exorable.

After that, the Lieutenant Colonell and Major came to Dun≈øtable, and brought another Order from the Generall, and read it to them, but could not prevaile, &c. But the Officers voted, that ≈øome of the Captaines, with my ≈øelfe, ≈øhould goe through their Quarters with Orders for them to march into Buckingham≈øhire. But when we came to Luton, we heard the Souldiers had a Randevouz off and from them≈øelves.

The ≈øaid Officers went to Captain Talhur≈øts quarter, and found a Guard ≈øet on him and his money, by his own men, and there the ≈øaid Captaines wounded or killed one or two men, and one Lieutenant was al≈øo wounded.

So I parted from the Captaines (after we had procured a Chirurgion) and told them, I would go to the Randevouz though I lo≈øt my own life, (as it was probable enough as they confe≈øt) and give them my Orders received of the Major; and accordingly I came to Dun≈øtable, and read my Orders to my owne men in the Town, the Randevouz being broken up, and gave them all the Arguments that was in me to march; but they told me their generall determination at the Randevouz was, that they would march to Readborne to a Randevouz; and ≈øo they did accordingly, without my con≈øent or approbation, &c. as many witne≈ø≈øes can te≈øtifie: and that night before they went to St. Albanes, they ≈øet a Guard upon me and my Colours, &c. and ≈øo they marched to S. Albanes, and lodged the Colours of the whole Regiment together, and ≈øo they went towards Hartford the next day.

I receiving a Letter from the Generall upon our march, commanding me and the Souldiers to ≈øtay where that Letter ≈øhould come to us. I told the Me≈ø≈øenger, I did not continue with them as commanding them, but to hinder an unju≈øt influence, or the enemies de≈øigne upon them, and to keep as much as I could, the Generals authority among them, which I was and am tender of. And I communicated my Orders to the Souldiers, and they all cryed out, they could not goe to that Randevouz, and that they were betraid, if they did. Whereupon the Souldiers petitioned the Generall, who ≈øent me a particular Order to march to Ware Randevouz.

THis Relation of Gaptain Bray I rather chu≈øe to make u≈øe of, then any of the other te≈øtimony, becau≈øe from him may be expected a more favourable relation then from any other, him≈øelfe being very much ≈øu≈øpected to be an a better, or at lea≈øt a favourer of the Mutiny: the≈øe things following being te≈øtified upon oath by Henry Lilburne, John Topping, William Dod, Rowland Stewart, William Hallowes, James Hart, Ethelburt Morgan, and Gabriel Erwood. Mo≈øt of whom were then con≈øiderable Officers in the ≈øame Regiment.

That at a Court of Warre held at Richmond, after the Generall had ordered the Regiment to march to Newca≈øtle, he ≈øaid that it was not fit for the Regiment to march thither, but to ≈øtay neere London, untill the Parliament had confirmed the propo≈øals of the Army, and the freedome of the people.

And that when the Regiment did march, the Colonels Company mutinying at St. Albanes, Captaine Bray did ≈øay that it were better for the Regiment to march back, then to goe forward, and that if the Colonels Company would march back, he would march in the head of them.

And when the Company did return back in a mutiny, he did march back in the head of them, and i≈ø≈øued out Warrants under his own hand to the Countrey, to bring in Hor≈øes to draw the Waggons back, when they ≈øhould have marched forward.

And the ≈øaid Captaine Bray in the height of the mutiny at Dun≈øtable, did ≈øpeake to this purpo≈øe, That the Parliament were our profe≈øt enemies, and that there was no vi≈øible Authority in the Kingdome but the Generall; and that the Generall was not infallible: His Lieutenant Colonell de≈øiring to know of him, whether he would goe to the head of his Company, and acquaint them, what orders he had received from the Generall, he an≈øwered, I ≈øhall not: and gave it as his opinion, That the way to get the Regiment to march, was to ≈øend a faire letter to the Agents of the five Regiments of Hor≈øe, and to get an Order from them.

Notwith≈øtanding the≈øe things, with much more of the ≈øame nature, was proved again≈øt him, yet he pretending he ≈øtayed with them, only to prevent the influence of others upon them, as in his foregoing Narrative, the Court Martiall was willing to take the be≈øt ≈øen≈øe of him they could, & did not proceed again≈øt him upon
this charge, which they would hardly have done, if they had been ≈øo much inclined to arbitrary tyranny, as him≈øelfe and others have endeavoured to repre≈øent them.
For if the circum≈øtances of this mutiny be impartially con≈øidered, what a di≈øtemper it wrought in the whole Army, nece≈øsitating a generall Randevouz to ≈øatisfie the Souldiers, &c.

What opportunities it gave to evill minded men to put both Army and Kingdome into a flame. Nay, how indu≈øtrious and active the Cavaliers agents were on the one hand, and our di≈øcontented friends on the other (who have alwayes pretended better things then their de≈øperate & bloody endeavours at that time, and often ≈øince doe demon≈øtrate they intend) there is not any man that ever knew in the lea≈øt mea≈øure, what belonged to the government and di≈øcipline of an Army, or of any other well governed Society, but will rather wonder, that every tenth man of them did not ≈øuffer, then think ≈øuch a ≈øtorm could be allayed with the executing of one man, though they ≈øhould under≈øtand no more of the Story, then what hath been related by Captain Bray.

Who in his Narrative takes no notice of their in≈øolent barbarous carriage towards their Officers and the Countrey, which was ≈øo horribly wicked and barbarous, that all the Felons which have ≈øuffered at Tyburn the≈øe twelve moneths, are not really guilty of ≈øo many horrid outrages, as they were in that time toward the Countrey and their Officers, the particulars thereof are too tedious to relate. Not any of their Officers except Captaine Bray, the Quarter-ma≈øter, and one more, as I remember, dur≈øt come neare them, ≈øome of them being pur≈øued many miles by their owne Souldiers, who ≈øwore as they pur≈øued them, they would be revenged on them, and did violently take away divers Hor≈øes in the Countrey in this pur≈øuit of their Officers, pretending their Officers were run away with their money, when they were forced to run to ≈øave their lives, there being one Lieutenant dangerou≈øly wounded by them. And at that time when this man, viz. Arnoll, was executed, there were divers other Officers could not be heard of, and the re≈øt did feare, that they were murthered and made away by their Souldiers.

And they did not exerci≈øe their rage and cruelty towards ≈øuch
in the Countrey, as were enemies to the cau≈øe, they were rai≈øed for, and paid to maintain, but on the contrary where ever they came in their march, inquired if there were any Round-heads in that Towne, and again≈øt them did they exerci≈øe their cruelty. Some hone≈øt men at St. Albanes, &c. informed me, that they were never ≈øo u≈øed by the Cavaliers as they u≈øed them, and did affirme, that if Captain Bray and the Quarter-ma≈øter had not been with them, who had a little influence upon them, they had been certainly plundred, if not murthered; many of whom have been, and ≈øtill are, as faithfull to the intere≈øt of the people, as the highe≈øt clamourer again≈øt this piece of nece≈øsitated ju≈øtice.

In this in≈øolent di≈øtemper did they march to the Randevouz, where they were drawn up by their Captaine Lieutenant Bray, and there ≈øtood with white papers in their Hats, as if they had been going to ingage with an enemy. When the Generall had viewed the re≈øt of the Army, he came to them, attended with his Officers, who commanded them to pull their papers out of their Hats, but they refu≈øed. Whereupon ≈øome Officers rode in among them, and plucked out the papers of ≈øome that were mo≈øt in≈øolent, and then the re≈øt began to ≈øubmit.

By this time ≈øome of their own ≈øcattered Officers were gotten up to the Randevouz, of whom the Generall and Officers enquired, who among them had been the principall Leaders and actors in this mutiny, and commanded them as they could e≈øpy them, to ≈øingle them out, and accordingly they drew out as I remember, eight or nine. A Court-martiall being called in the place, they were all found notoriou≈øly guilty of particular facts in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and were there adjudged by the Lawes and Ordinances of warre to dye; and accordingly ≈øentence of death was pronounced upon them, and afterward referred to a Lot, all pardoned but one, on whom the Lot ≈øhould fall, which was this Arnoll, who was pre≈øently ≈øhot to death in the place. And I well remember ≈øome of the Officers of that Regiment, did much rejoyce in the ju≈øt hand of God, directing the Lot upon that man, whom they had ob≈øerved to be more notoriou≈øly guilty then any other in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe. The Lot is ca≈øt into the lap, but the whole dispo≈øing thereof i ‚Ä¢ of the Lord, Pro. 16.33.

The next per≈øon for whom the Army hath been clamoured again≈øt,
for their procedings with, is William Thom≈øon, a Corporal in Captain Pichforts Troop, in Colonell Whaleys Regiment, who was que≈øtioned at a Court-martiall in the Regiment, for drunkenne≈ø≈øe, gaming, and quarrelling, The ≈øtory followeth: The ≈øaid Thom≈øon being at a Tavern in Colebrooke, after ≈øome time ≈øpent in drinking & carou≈øing, he fell into play for money; finding him≈øelf in danger to lo≈øe, he began to quarrell with the man he played with, who perceiving his de≈øigne, took the ≈øtakes into his hand: Upon which Mr. Thom≈øon laid violent hands upon the Gentleman, tore him by the haire, and by force po≈ø≈øe≈øt him≈øelfe of the ≈øtakes. In the mean while the Gentlewoman of the Hou≈øe being putting her husband to bed, hearing a great noi≈øe of quarrelling below, came running down among them, and endeavoured to part them: upon which Thom≈øon threw her down, kickt her on the face, and mo≈øt gro≈øly beat and abu≈øed the ≈øervants for ≈øtriving to part them. And he being not able to have his will on them him≈øelfe, goeth away, and not long after returned againe with ≈øome other of his companions, and in the dead time of the night forced into the hou≈øe with his drawne ≈øword, wounded three or foure of the ≈øervants, laid felony to the charge of the Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øe of the Hou≈øe, and two others, for robbing him of 20. l. of gold and ≈øilver, tooke one man away pri≈øoner, viz. William Mou≈øe, threatning him to tye him neck and heels together, if he would not confe≈ø≈øe his money; notwith≈øtanding by his owne confe≈øsion afterwards he lo≈øt none. All which is te≈øtified at large again≈øt him by Mr. Miles of Colebrook and his wife, Thomas Winall, and George Weare, and mo≈øt of it confe≈øt by him≈øelfe.

Upon debate of the premi≈øes, he was adjudged by the Councell of warre, to be ca≈øhiered at the head of the Regiment the next Randevouz: which ≈øentence he would not ≈øubmit unto, but endeavoured to get the Souldiers of the Regiment to ≈øtand by him in this quarrell: from which irregular mutinous carriages proceeded that which followeth.

Upon the 28. of October, the Regiment had a Randevouz upon Odiam Heath in the County of Surrey, the ≈øaid Thom≈øon ≈øtill abiding with the Regiment, notwith≈øtanding hee was ca≈øhiered ≈øix weekes before, and had received ≈øeverall orders to depart the Quarters.

The Major of the Regiment did there endevour according to the judgement of the Court, actually to ca≈øhiere him at the head of the Regiment, which he in a peremptory mutinous manner refu≈øed to ≈øubmit unto. Upon which there was a new charge exhibited again≈øt him, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øeverall Articles, the heads whereof are as followeth.

Fir≈øt, that the ≈øaid Thom≈øon at or about the tenth of September, 1647. did a≈ø≈øume the title of a Souldier in the Army, under the command of his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, and came to the Regiment of Colonell Fleetwood, being at a Randevouz, and there ≈øpake to and in the hearing of all the Souldiers, ≈øeverall ≈øeditious and mutinous words, and delivered ≈øeverall ≈øeditious papers, ≈øome written, others printed.

Secondly, he endeavoured to make mutiny in the ≈øaid Regiment, by pretending he had brought a letter from the Agents of 15. Regiments, and ≈øaid he came to the Souldiers, and not to the Officers, affirming there were accu≈øations again≈øt the Officers of the Army, labouring thereby to make a divi≈øion betweene the Officers and the Souldiers, pre≈øsing the Souldiers to ≈øub≈øcribe his papers. All which were proved upon oath by Captain Griffith Loyd, Captain Gilmond Taylor, and Thomas Scot Trooper, all in Col Fleetwoods Regiment.

Since which time he gathered together a company of men in Armes, whom hee quartered upon the Countrey, calling them his Troop, and they him Captain; with whom hee marched to a Gentlemans hou≈øe in E≈ø≈øex, who had a ≈øuit depending in Law with another about a Title in land, whom he by force & violence di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øt, taking his Tenants and Servants pri≈øoners, driving them before him in miery way in the night, pricking them on with his ≈øwords point in a mo≈øt barbarous and cruell manner. And within a few dayes after, he was again taken on the Road, with a party of other men, whom he had deluded into his evill cour≈øes; and had found about him a great black Periwig, and a fal≈øe Beard, which they brought back againe with him to White Hall. And what his actions & end hath been ≈øince, is ≈øo notorious, I ≈øhall not trouble you with the relation of it here. The third per≈øon of this number that hath been proceeded again≈øt for mutiny, and for whom ≈øo many are offended, is Robert Lockyer, a man unknown to me untill the time of his impri≈øonment: ≈øince which time I have inquired of him, and have heard a very ill report from the mouthes of ≈øuch, who ≈øpake it with no delight, and yet had cau≈øe and opportunity to inquire into, and ob≈øerve his demeanour: but there being a relation of the proceedings of the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe again≈øt him, with the cau≈øe thereof, already printed, I ≈øhall not trouble you with any thing of that again; only I mu≈øt ob≈øerve to you his un≈øtable demeanor in the time of his ≈øuffrings, while he was before the Councell, the witne≈ø≈øes giving their te≈øtimonies again≈øt him viva voce, he could not deny any thing of that which was laid to his charge, but did endeavour to evade it, with ≈øuch criticall cro≈ø≈øe interrogatories to the witne≈ø≈øes, as di≈øcovered more of wit and ≈øubtilty, then of godline≈ø≈øe or integrity in him.

The next morning after he was ≈øentenced, he ≈øeemed to be very ≈øen≈øible of his mi≈øcarriage, and ≈øorry for his fault, and did de≈øire directions, what ≈øhould be the be≈øt way for him to make his mind known to the Generall, &c. And there being then a Petition drawn, which the other five that were to ca≈øt lots, had ≈øub≈øcribed, he de≈øired to ≈øet his hand to it, and joyn with them in it; he was advi≈øed to be carefull what he did, and was told, that it was not a time to di≈ø≈øemble neither with God nor Man, and that the words of the petition which he de≈øired to ≈øub≈øcribe, and his former di≈øcour≈øe, did not agree. Upon which, having heard the petition read ≈øeverall times to him, he ≈øet his hand to it, in which he hath the≈øe expre≈øsions, That the Generall would be plea≈øed, out of his wonted clemency and goodne≈ø≈øe, to pa≈ø≈øe by that unwi≈øe and unlawful action of theirs, and give them their lives for a prey; and we do vow and prote≈øt before the Almighty God, that we are heartily ≈øorry for our faults, and doe promi≈øe, as in his all-≈øeeing eye, never to doe the like action again, nor ≈øuffer it to be done, if we can hinder it with our lives.

Then within a few houres after, there being a warrant ≈øigned for his execution, he changed his mind again, as if he had not been the ≈øame man, and began to ≈øpeak evill of his Judges, and the Law by which he was judged, &c. and to ju≈øtifie him≈øelf as an innocent ≈øufferer in a good cau≈øe, &c. and ≈øo continued untill he died.

Now that which I ≈øhould de≈øire the Reader to ob≈øerve in this brief narrative of the≈øe three mens faults and puni≈øhments, is this: Fir≈øt, what ground there is for the≈øe great clamours again≈øt the Army, for

The ≈øecond thing I de≈øire may be minded in the narration is, what ground the great pretenders of Englands liberties can have to think, their good cau≈øe is either, intere≈øted in, or prejudiced by, the puni≈øhment of the≈øe evill actions, unle≈ø≈øe that which was puni≈øhed in the≈øe men, be the liberty they ≈øo much contend for, which mu≈øt needs be a liberty in particulars to the prejudice of the generall.

And for Mr. Lockyer, whom they are plea≈øed to canonize a Martyr ≈øince his death, there is le≈ø≈øe to be ≈øaid for him upon that con≈øideration, then for either of the other two: for he and tho≈øe which mutined with him, did not ≈øo much as pretend common right and freedome, nor had the lea≈øt colour of any one grievance lay upon them, except their not having their pay before it was either received by their Officers for them, or due unto them, which is a new grievance never heard on before in an Army. I cannot pa≈ø≈øe by the≈øe words, without ob≈øerving ≈øomething from them: His friends lamentation over him is, that he ≈øhould be condemned for nothing but asking his pay, and his own words are, For contending for his pay. Nay, in many ca≈øes where the Souldier hath cau≈øle≈øly and wrongfully pro≈øecuted his Officer at a Court-Martiall, and yet hath not had the lea≈øt reproof from the Court, ≈øo tender have they been of di≈øcouraging the Souldiers in this particular. But the ca≈øe of Mr. Lockyer and the re≈øt of his a≈ø≈øociates, are much different from all the≈øe ca≈øes: For fir≈øt, they had no pay due, they having been better paid ≈øince they came la≈øt into London, then ever

And further, they did not only demand their pay in manner afore≈øaid before it was due unto them, but refu≈øed to march, di≈øobeyed the commands of their Officers, while they unju≈øtly quarrell for their wages before they had earned it, they refu≈øe to do their work, for which they were paid‚ñ™ and did not onely di≈øobey their Officers commands, but re≈øi≈øt them in the doing of their duty, forcibly ≈øeize upon the Colours, detain them from their Officers when demanded; and this not done in a ≈øudden hurly-burly, or an heat of blood, but with deliberation, continuing in this po≈øture neere two dayes and nights, gathered them≈øelves together into a ≈øtrong hou≈øe, and there kept it again≈øt their Officers. When their Colonell and Officers came in love and pitie towards them, per≈øwading them by rea≈øon to con≈øider with them≈øelves, what ≈øad events mu≈øt follow, if they nece≈øsitated them to u≈øe extremity; putting them in mind, how comfortably they had ventured their lives together again≈øt the common enemy, promi≈øing them all they either did or could de≈øire, if they would be ruled, and march after the Regiment. The next thing ob≈øerved out of tho≈øe words quoted of his, is this, Which as he often ≈øaid, had it been for the freedome and liberty of this Nation, it would have added much to his comfort.
